channel.title: College?
channel.description: What College do you recommended me to go to? I REALLY I wanna go to UC Berkeley, but at the same time I want to attend Standford. What college do you guys suggest?

item.title: College?
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

[quote=“m1lkman, post:20, topic:396203”][quote author=HcoJustin link=topic=493372.msg3607581#msg3607581 date=1306262837]

I go to a community college and if I was actually paying for my education I would be pretty disappointed.

This. After you get your general education out of the way, you can transfer to a university for your degree. The first 2 years are basically redoing high school so theres no point to pay absurd amounts for it.
[/quote]

Shouldn’t you get your general courses out of the way in highschool so you can do the classes you actually want to do? That’s what I’m doing.[/quote]

You can’t. You must redo your general education if you continue past high school. (In the US anyways). This takes about 2 years, and then you start focusing on your major. If you just want an associates you can do that at a community college side by side with the GE.

As far as AP classes go, if you score high enough on the test you can send the scores to college and it counts for one of the required classes. So I got to skip one course of math, which helped a little bit.

My school never offered the program to get college credits for taking classes, so I’m out of luck there.

Read full topic

item.title: College?
item.dc:creator: @m.dog311 m.dog311
item.description:

[quote=“Loveandpower, post:21, topic:396203”][quote author=m1lkman link=topic=493372.msg3607767#msg3607767 date=1306274959]

I go to a community college and if I was actually paying for my education I would be pretty disappointed.

This. After you get your general education out of the way, you can transfer to a university for your degree. The first 2 years are basically redoing high school so theres no point to pay absurd amounts for it.

Shouldn’t you get your general courses out of the way in highschool so you can do the classes you actually want to do? That’s what I’m doing.
[/quote]Not everybody gets into AP courses.[/quote]
AP courses don’t count for college credits either, iirc… So they wouldn’t affect your college at all… My high school doesn’t even offer AP courses, however, they offer actual college classes (worth credits that can be transferred to most colleges).

item.title: College?
item.dc:creator: @iCreatedHorror Ryan
item.description:
@iCreatedHorror wrote:

[quote=“HcoJustin, post:18, topic:396203”][quote author=Newty link=topic=493372.msg3607568#msg3607568 date=1306261902]
I go to a community college and if I was actually paying for my education I would be pretty disappointed.
[/quote]

This. After you get your general education out of the way, you can transfer to a university for your degree. The first 2 years are basically redoing high school so theres no point to pay absurd amounts for it.[/quote]
Unless you are going into a special program which follows certain requirements. For example: I want to get into veterinary school, so (going to be a freshman this year in college), I will be majoring in biology and meeting certain requirements to increase my chances of getting into Vet. school. Luckily, the college has extremely high acceptance rates into school after.

But, I do know a bunch of friends going into Community College first, then transferring as a money saver. It really depends.

Read full topic

item.title: College?
item.dc:creator: @m.dog311 m.dog311
item.description:
@m.dog311 wrote:

Whatever you can get into and afford… Really, the first 4 years don’t make much of a difference anywhere because it’s mostly bullshit, general ed classes… Get your first 4 years out of the way at a decently local college (not community college, like I live in Pittsburgh, so University of Pittsburgh would be a good one). After that, transfer to a larger college to get your masters, doctorate, w/e. Not only that, but if your college has more than one campus, you don’t really need to get into the main one. It’s nice, but it doesn’t make much of a difference. University of Pittsburgh main campus, Pitt Greensburg (I’m naming ones close to me, I’m not sure of the colleges around you), and all the other campuses all appear as the same exact thing on your diploma, and you’re getting close to the same education at all of them.

The cost of going to these schools is a big thing to look at too…
UC Berkley: http://grad.berkeley.edu/admissions/cost_fees.shtml
Stanford: http://www.howtogetin.com/colleges/stanford-university/expenses.php
I’m assuming you’re a resident of California, based on Berkley and Stanford both being in Califnornia, but look at the CSU’s tuition. http://www.calstate.edu/SAS/fa_coa.shtml
It is considerably cheaper, and definitely won’t leave you in a massive debt like the other to (~70 grand for 4 years compared to ~160 grand at the other two).

Honestly, it’s up to you though. They’re both great schools, but I truthfully think they’re overkill for an undergrad.

Read full topic

item.title: College?
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

Mack n cheese:

community colleges > universitys

Technical college > community colleges > universitys

At least, if the counselor for the tech. college is nice. The one that tried getting in at a tech. college asked where else I was thinking about going (she played the “go to the one you want to, scheme”), she got really cocky and snobby. All I herd was this "Well… (she paused) Tell me how you like going to a (she put emphases on next 2 words) COMMUNITY COLLEGE rather than a (another emphases for these 2) TECHNICAL COLLEGE. I said, “Sure, because I wont be going there after that statement”, and hung up the phone.

@TOPIC - Knowing the best college to go to goes with what you want to develop as a career.

Read full topic
